title: Quiz 3: Sampling Methods
description: Test your ability to identify and apply different sampling techniques and understand sampling terminology.

questions.question: What is the definition of a 'Study Population'?

options.text: The entire group of individuals, events, or objects having common observable characteristics.
Only the people who are sick in the hospital.
The small group selected to represent the whole.
The list of names used to draw the sample.

questions.explanation: The study population is the total group you are interested in (e.g., all under-fives). The small group selected is the 'sample'.

questions.question: Match the sampling method to its description:

pairs.right: Every unit has an equal chance (e.g., lottery method).
Selecting every 'nth' individual from a list.
Dividing population into subgroups and sampling from each.
Randomly selecting intact groups (e.g., schools) not individuals.

questions.explanation: Simple Random = Lottery; Systematic = Nth number; Stratified = Subgroups/Strata; Cluster = Groups/Locations.
questions.hint: Stratified involves layers (strata); Cluster involves bunches.

questions.question: In a systematic sample of 1000 women where you want to select 10 women, what is the sampling interval (n)?
questions.explanation: 1000 divided by 10 equals 100. You would pick every 100th file.
questions.hint: Perform the division in the formula.

questions.question: Which of the following are Non-Probability (Biased) sampling methods?
questions.explanation: Convenience, Quota, and Purposive sampling do not give everyone an equal chance and are thus non-probability methods.

questions.question: Bias occurs when the sample is not randomly selected or interviewers do not follow a consistent method.
questions.explanation: Bias introduces systematic errors into the data, often due to poor selection or inconsistent procedures.
questions.hint: Bias means the results are skewed away from the truth.

questions.question: Order the steps for drawing a Simple Random Sample using the lottery method:

items.text: Make a list of all units/give each a number
Write numbers on small pieces of paper
Fold papers and put in a box
Pick the required number of pieces

questions.question: What is the term for 'a list of all units that make up the study population' from which a sample is drawn?
questions.explanation: A sampling frame is the source list (e.g., a register, a map) from which the sample is selected.

questions.question: When is 'Cluster Sampling' most useful?

options.text: When the population is scattered or no list of individuals exists.
When the population is very small and concentrated.
When you want to study specific strata like age groups.
When you want to interview people as they arrive at a clinic.

questions.explanation: Cluster sampling is used when a sampling frame of individuals is hard to get or the population is spread over a large area.

questions.question: ___BLANK___ sampling involves selecting cases or units as they become available, such as interviewing everyone at a clinic on a specific day.
questions.explanation: Convenience sampling picks whoever is easiest to reach (convenient).
questions.hint: It is convenient for the researcher.

questions.question: What is 'Sampling Error'?

options.text: Errors arising because a small sample may not perfectly reflect the whole population's characteristics.
Mistakes made by the interviewer when writing answers.
Errors made when coding data into the computer.

questions.explanation: Sampling error is the natural variation that occurs because you are looking at a subset, not the whole population.
questions.hint: It happens even if the method is perfect, just because the sample is small.
